title: Friday, 24th March, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
BE11:03am

Oh hello. Hi. Welcome. Markets Live time again.

BE11:05am

BE11:05am

Which means I get to chose the picture, which today is ....

11:05 am

Ackman, of course.

BE11:06am

To mark the news -- which broke too late for us yesterday -- that Pershing Square's coming to London!

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Always good to see dynamic, exciting investment opportunities in the home market.

BE11:06am

St. Peter Port, Guernsey, 23 March 2017 //‐ Pershing Square Holdings, Ltd. (ticker: PSH:NA) today announced that PSH intends to apply for admission of its ordinary shares to the Official List of the UK Listing Authority and to trading on the Main Market of the London Stock Exchange (“Admission”).
Following Admission, it is expected that PSH will be eligible for inclusion in the FTSE UK Index Series, including the FTSE All‐Share and FTSE 250 indices.  The Company’s listing on Euronext Amsterdam will not be affected.  Following Admission, investors will be able to trade PSH shares on both markets with PSH shares being quoted and traded in Sterling in London and in USD on Euronext Amsterdam.
PSH has decided to seek a premium listing in London in an effort to improve market access for investors, increase liquidity in PSH shares, and assist in narrowing the current discount to net asset value at which PSH shares trade.

BE11:06am

Yup, sure, that's right. It's the lack of liquidity that's the problem.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

I mean, the share price is down 40% since the Euronext float whereas the NAV's only down 30%! It's an inexplicable anomaly!

BE11:07am

BE11:08am

Clearly, that 10% discount to NAV is down to illiquidity.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Rather than the attractions of locking yourself into the fates of a punting machine that's crushed about a third of other people's cash in just over two years.

BE11:08am

Okay, yes, I know ... investing's difficult.

BE11:08am

Nevertheless, you have to try really hard to lose more money than Ackman.

11:08 am
BE11:09am

Here's the chart since the float versus a semi-random selection of benchmarks.

BE11:09am

BE11:09am

(Right click and open new window to embiggen.)

11:09 am
BE11:09am

BE11:09am

Jefferies certainly thinks so.

BE11:10am

Action on the discount: This welcome proposal reflects the first overt action by the fund to address its 'unacceptable' discount. PSH's structural features limit its ability to use other, more traditional, discount management tools. For example, share buybacks are made problematic by its ownership limits, structural debt, and more often than not, being an insider on its own portfolio. A LSE premium listing therefore offers the potential to instead tackle the discount by making the shares more liquid, investable, and creating demand from index-tracking funds by virtue of FTSE inclusion.

11:09 am
BE11:10am

Ancillary benefits: Some of the specific requirements of a premium LSE listing will also naturally serve to make PSH more shareholder friendly. A GBP quote is a base requirement of many UK investors, and the listing also entails modifications to PSH's voting arrangements. While the existing VoteCo voting structure is likely to be retained in order to comply with U.S. securities laws, PSH shareholders will have to be fully enfranchised regarding certain matters, such as share buyback/issuance authority, related party transactions, material changes to the investment policy, and the re-election of connected directors.

BE11:10am

Other considerations: There is an argument to suggest multiple trading venues could fragment liquidity in the shares, remembering the impact on liquidity of having multiple share classes was something PSH appeared keen to avoid at the time of its IPO. However, we feel broadening the potential investor base for a single class of shares should increase overall liquidity over both venues. Importantly, FTSE inclusion at the next potential entry point in June will be dependent on PSH demonstrating sufficient trading liquidity in London within a relatively tight test window.

BE11:10am

Positive newsflow: The action to address the discount adds to PSH's recent run of positive newsflow, albeit set against a negative start to the year in NAV performance terms (down 2.8% at the point of this week's NAV). The sale of the remaining position in Valeant announced last week has eliminated a perceived source of further drag on performance, while the presence of two undisclosed portfolio positions signals embedded value within the portfolio, and could help shift it more towards 'bread and butter' activist positions. That said, the ultimate driver of sentiment will continue to be a much needed recovery in NAV performance, which, as ever, is largely contingent on the performance of the concentrated portfolio core.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Smiths posted impressive 2017 interim results, beating our EBIT and sales estimates by 15% and 1%, respectively. We are 4.7% ahead of company-compiled EBIT consensus for FY17.

BE11:16am

John Crane margins beat our 1H estimates by 270 bp, driven by improved aftermarket mix of +3% (GSe: -1%). Detection posted impressive organic growth of 12%, following FY16 growth of 9%. All segments except ports and borders (tough comp) grew. The divisional margin uplift was partly driven by a mix of higher-margin contracts, which are set to moderate in 2H. Medical expects an improvement in 2H organic sales.

BE11:17am

Importantly, cash conversion continues to improve, posting 115% (vs. 102% in 2016), driven by improved W/C, and we believe it will weigh positively on the multiple. Smiths trades on a 10x 2018E EV/EBIT. Morpho Detection is at the final stages of all regulatory approvals . 2017 outlook remains ‘unchanged’ but we see upside risk to consensus on the back of these results. Management has emphasised that 2H weighting may be more fairly balanced than recent years. Today’s results imply a 50% 2H EBIT weighting vs. a historical weighting of 56% (2016: 57%).

In today's globalized world, authorities around the world are confronted with an increasing number of threats to citizens, businesses and institutions.

Safran Identity & Security provides them with an extensive range of qualified and certified technology-based solutions to efficiently detect explosives and other threats.

Whether it's passengers crossing borders, airplanes carrying cargo or critical infrastructure in operation, governments across the globe have to deal with a multitude of threats. To help them do so, Safran Identity & Security has developed fast, reliable detection solutions for explosives, narcotics and other dangerous substances.

BE11:19am

Conclusion: a good beat of 2% on sales and 14% on operating profit vs consensus on the headline numbers. We note that there has been some pull forward benefit from 2H into 1H and so FY expectations remain unchanged (updated consensus is for operating profit for FY17 of £553m). There will also be a step up in tax rate from ~26% in FY17 to a 30-31% range from FY18 due to the roll off of some one off benefits. We estimate a 7% headwind from this tax rate step up to FY18 numbers. Net net we see the underlying trends as broadly encouraging with clear signs of stabilization in the Crane business and ongoing strength in Detection, though headwinds in Medical remain somewhat of an offset. On an organic basis we expect minimal changes to consensus estimates but there should still be a 6-7% downgrade to consensus FY18 EPS due to the step up in tax rate. We expect the shares to open solidly but could fade through the day as the higher tax rate impact feeds through consensus estimates.

BE11:21am

As a footnote, the shares have had a big rally since start 2016 but are pretty much flat from mid 2013, when it rejected that bid for the medical side.

PM11:23am

After a strong rise in March the euro-zone Composite PMI suggests that the economy might have had its strongest quarter in two years in Q1. The rise in the headline composite index, from 56.0 to 56.7, was stronger than the consensus forecast of a slight fall to 55.8 and left it at a 71-month high. The overall rise was driven by pick-ups in both the services PMI and manufacturing PMIs. On the basis of its past reasonably strong relationship with quarterly GDP growth, an average of the PMI in Q1 appears consistent with a gain of about 0.6%. That would be an acceleration from the 0.4% recorded in Q4 and would be the strongest growth rate since Q1 2015.

PM11:24am

The limited country breakdown revealed sharp rises in both the German and French Composite PMIs. The German index picked up from 56.1 to 57.0, while the French PMI recorded an even sharper rise from 55.9 to 57.6. The French PMI is now ahead of the German equivalent for the first time since August 2012. Looking ahead, the euro-zone future output index rose to its highest level in the series’ short four-year history, suggesting that firms expect economic strength to be maintained over the next 12 months. In all then, some encouraging news for the region. But while the output prices index increased further, there is still slack in the labour market and wage growth is set to remain subdued. As such, policymakers at the ECB are unlikely to be convinced that recent signs of a pick-up in activity will translate into sustained upward pressure on inflation.

PM11:24am

11:24 am
PM11:25am

Euro area March “flash” composite PMIs came in stronger than our above consensus expectations at 56.7, a 71-month high, on better confidence in both manufacturing and services sectors. Within composite PMIs, new orders posted the highest reading since April 2011, underpinning record high hiring intentions. In addition, backlog of works reached an almost six-year peak, signaling that firms are facing significant operating capacity pressures. Together with a stronger future output index, this suggests that confidence should remain on an upward trend in the months to come despite elevated political uncertainty. Indeed, it seems that euro area firms are ignoring external uncertainty (Brexit, Trump policies) as external demand has remained strong so far helped by a weak euro. Meanwhile uncertainty related to French Presidential elections appears to have been shrugged off: French firms are expecting pro-business policies post the May elections, which suggests they do not see a Le Pen victory as a likely scenario. In terms of countries, the strong euro area print was thus supported by booming confidence in France, but also improving sentiment in Germany. Elsewhere (eg, Italy, Spain and Ireland) we see some slight decline from elevated levels (c.-0.5 point on average in the manufacturing and services sectors). Overall, today's solid PMIs have added upside risks to our 0.4% q/q Q1 GDP forecast.

PM11:25am

· German composite PMI came in above expectations, rising to 57.0 (+0.9 point) – a 70-month high. The composite rise was supported by buoyant confidence in both the manufacturing and services sectors. Positively, this was driven by dynamic new orders - panelists mentioned strong external demand which encouraged firms to hire staff (the composite employment component was close to a six-year high). Rising operating capacity pressures (elevated backlog of works) was accompanied by stronger inflationary pressures. Indeed, higher input costs on the back of elevated commodity prices, a weak euro and higher wages were partly transmitted to clients pushing the composite output prices index to the highest level since June 2011. This is consistent with our view that headline inflation will average 1.8% this year. On the growth front, our Q1 PMI-based GDP indicator stands at 0.8% q/q, highlighting upside risks to our 0.5% q/q forecast.

PM11:25am

· French composite PMIs surprised once again to the upside in March at 57.6 (+1.7 points) - a 70-month high - on marked strengthening in services confidence. The headline services PMI jumped to 58.5 (+2.1 points), the highest print since May 2011. The increase was broad based in terms of components, with stronger outstanding and new business feeding into higher hiring intentions. Business expectations also strengthened (standing more than four points above their historical average), as panelists see favourable economic conditions and expect pro-business policies after May’s Presidential elections. The picture was also positive in the manufacturing sector, with the headline bouncing back to 53.4 (+1.2 points). New orders reached an almost six-year high, supported by solid demand in US and Asia. This led to some accumulation in backlog of works and rise in future output, highlighting building operating capacity pressures. Overall, optimistic March PMIs point to solid growth in Q1, with our PMI-based GDP indicator standing at 0.4% q/q, in line with our growth forecast. This is also broadly consistent with the March INSEE survey, which remains positively oriented despite some moderation

BE11:29am

The average daily loss of revenue is estimated to be greater than $1m, as the directive impacts the Bulyanhulu and Buzwagi mines. To date, operations at the mine sites have not been affected, as there is sufficient capacity to store concentrate in containers. However, beyond April, capacity will be limited and ACA will have to reassess production levels, should a resolution on the concentrate export ban not be in sight.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

And RBC.

BE11:30am

As we highlighted in our resumption of coverage note earlier in the week, the situation remains uncertain. This said, we continue to expect that the lack of economic rationale for a smelter to be built in Tanzania will allow for concentrate exports to resume eventually. The $1m of revenue per day that is being deferred is in line with our expectations (being ~30% of revenues). Assuming the ban is lifted at some stage, this working capital build will unwind. For now Acacia is slowing its spending at its operations to help alleviate cash pressures and to tighten the losses, which could potentially have an eventual impact on 2017 production levels. Acacia will be able to continue to store concentrates indefinitely, but in this release management has suggested that it will make a further decision in April on current operations. With our unadjusted base case revenues of $1.157bn for 2017, the impact to the Tanzanian economy, which has a ~$46bn total GDP is clear and we would think any protracted shut down of operations will likely be avoided. This said, our target price of 450p (based on 1.0x NAV and 8x P/CF and a $1,300/oz gold price without any adjustments to tax rates/stakes, etc) only supports a Sector Perform rating.

BE11:32am

Acacia accounted for ~2% of Tanzania's GDP in 2014, according to an old JP Morgan note.

Mr Li compared the Hong Kong stock market to a city that is reasonably well-run but has “a few dark alleys and little corners” that ordinary people and the police normally avoid.

However, he added, a surge of “tourists” who don’t know better are now venturing into these less-than-salubrious areas and getting “beaten up by some local gangsters and others”.

The solution is to send in the police and put up some CCTV cameras, he added wryly.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

That's the one. And that headline's accurate. They've run the numbers over a century.

PM11:39am

Excellent

BE11:40am

A lot has changed in 100 years but the fundamental aspects of banking have not. Indeed, balance sheets post reform will look more like those in the period 1916-90 than post 1990. A lot can be drawn from the ROE that management were prepared to accept over this period, no doubt giving consideration to COE. We analyse Barclays since 1896 as a proxy for the sector, making extensive use of archived data.

11:39 am
BE11:40am

Yeah, really. Barclays since 1896.

PM11:40am

Blimey

BE11:41am

Barclays' "true" ROTE averaged 10% for the period 1916-90, a function of leverage and liquidity ratios not dissimilar to those we expect post structural reform. Variance between banks is observed over time, but this tends to be temporary. Taking into account prevailing conditions, we expect sector ROTE to settle no higher than 11%, again with limited variance between banks.

11:41 am
PM11:41am

Exane notes are banned from the usual place, otherwise I'd ask to share this

BE11:41am

A number of factors justify an elevated short term discount rate - familiarisation with higher IFRS9 volatility is a particular concern. But our work combined with a regression based analysis of equity beta, asset beta and leverage suggests COE could fall towards 8% over time. It is important to note that higher absolute valuations rely on no major increase in market ERP. But to the extent that the idiosyncratic beta of UK banks is much higher than it should be, there is still a relative advantage to the sector.

BE11:41am

Essentially our argument is that the market has priced in lower future returns driven by higher capital and liquidity but has not fully adjusted COE for this. Beta in 2016 at 1.6 compares to the 1.25 that we expect post balance sheet normalisation. In a relative sense, we conclude that Barclays looks attractive and we upgrade to Outperform. RBS looks fairly valued and we upgrade to Neutral.

BE11:53am

GRAND CAYMAN, CAYMAN ISLANDS--(Marketwired - March 24, 2017) - Tethys Petroleum Limited ("Tethys" or the "Company") (TSX:TPL)(LSE:TPL) today announces that it has applied to the United Kingdom Listing Authority ("UKLA") to cancel the standard listing of the Company's ordinary shares (the "Shares") from the Official List of the UKLA and the cancellation of trading in the Shares on the Main Market of the London Stock Exchange (together, the "Cancellation"), following a determination by the Company that the costs of maintaining a dual listing on the London and Toronto stock exchanges is unnecessarily expensive for a company of Tethys' size. Following the Cancellation, the Shares will continue to trade on the Toronto Stock Exchange which should provide shareholders with liquidity and places sufficient corporate governance requirements upon the Company. Further, the Company's conclusion, that the London listing be cancelled, is supported by the limited trading and liquidity of the Shares on the London Stock Exchange (meaning that limited benefit is brought by that listing).

Pursuant to Listing Rule 5.2.8, the Company announces that the cancellation notice period has now commenced and cancellation is expected to take effect at 7:00 am on Tuesday 2 May, 2017.

The Company currently has two share registers, a register maintained by Capita Asset Services in the UK and a register maintained by TSX Trust Company in Canada. It is the Company's intention to transfer the shareholdings on the Capita Asset Services register to the TSX Trust Company register following the Cancellation which should result in further cost savings for the Company. Those shareholders affected will be contacted about this with further details in due course.
